'''Boogie Bill Webb''' (March 24, 1924 – August 22, 1990)<ref name="Dead"/> was an [[United States|American]] [[Louisiana blues]] and [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] [[guitarist]], [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]]. Webb's own style of music combined Mississippi [[country blues]] with [[New Orleans]] R&B.<ref name="AMG"/> His best known [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] were "Bad Dog" and "Drinkin' and Stinkin'".<ref name="Dead"/> Despite a lengthy, albeit stuttering, career, Webb nevertheless only released one [[album]].<ref name="AMG"/>

==Biography==
Born in [[Jackson, Mississippi|Jackson]], [[Mississippi]], Webb's first guitar at the age of eight was stringed with screen wire and made from a [[Cigar box guitar|cigar box]].<ref name="AMG"/>  His greatest influence was [[Tommy Johnson (blues musician)|Tommy Johnson]].<ref name="Sunday">{{cite web|url=http://sundayblues.org/archives/tag/boogie-bill-webb |title=Big Road Blues |publisher=Sundayblues.org |date= |accessdate=May 21, 2010}}</ref> With a real guitar obtained whist a teenager, in 1947 Webb won a [[talent show]], and subsequently briefly appeared in the [[musical film]], ''The Jackson Jive,'' before settling in New Orleans in 1952.<ref name="AMG"/>

Webb obtained a [[recording contract]] with [[Imperial Records]], after his friendship with [[Fats Domino]] led to his introduction to [[Dave Bartholomew]].<ref name="Sunday"/> In 1953 Webb released his debut [[single (music)|single]], "Bad Dog," a non commercial slice of [[country music|country]] [[boogie-woogie]].  Frustrated by lack of recognition, Webb relocated to [[Chicago]], where he worked in various factories.<ref  name="AMG"/> In Chicago, Webb met and sat in with [[Muddy Waters]], [[John Lee Hooker]], [[Jimmy Reed]], and [[Chuck Berry]].<ref>{{cite book
| first= David
| last= Evans
| year= 2002
| title= Big Road Blues: Tradition and creativity in the folk blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University of California Press 
| location= Berkeley, California
| isbn= 0-520-03484-8
| page= 117}}</ref>

Webb returned to New Orleans in 1959 to work as a [[stevedore]], performing music infrequently. However, in 1968 he recorded several songs for the  [[folklorist]] David Evans, which eventually appeared on the [[Arhoolie Records]] album ''Roosevelt Holts and His Friends''.<ref name="Sunday"/> The 1972 [[compilation album]], ''The Legacy of Tommy Johnson'' contained five tracks performed by Webb.<ref>[http://www.wirz.de/music/stovafrm.htm Wirz.de/music] - accessed May 2010</ref>

A combination of the exposure at home and in [[Europe]] led to visits to Webb from blues [[fan (person)|fans]], and invitations to tour. In 1982 Webb appeared at the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[Utrecht (city)|Utrecht]] Festival.<ref name="AMG"/> Finally in 1989, with financial assistance from the Louisiana Endowment for the Humanities, Webb released ''Drinkin' and Stinkin'''.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p568/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Boogie Bill Webb |author=Ankeny, Jason |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=May 21, 2010}}</ref> His experience of encountering three drunken women, who had been out drinking for three days without bathing, inspired the [[lyrics]] for the title track of the album.<ref>{{cite book
| first= David
| last= Evans
| year= 2002
| title= Big Road Blues: Tradition and creativity in the folk blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= University of California Press 
| location= Berkeley, California
| isbn= 0-520-03484-8
| page= 132}}</ref>

Boogie Bill Webb died in New Orleans in August 1990, at the age of 66.<ref name="Dead">[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/1990.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com (1990)] - accessed May 2010</ref>
